questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the OPD with rapid weight gain and easy bruisability over the past 1 month. She was started on oral prednisolone for dermatomyositis 2 months ago. On examination, moon facies and abdominal striae are noted. Her BP is 160/110 mm Hg. Which of the following pathological changes is seen in this condition?

choices.text: Corticotroph cells with homogenous and pale cytoplasm
Accumulation of keratin filaments in adrenal cells
Eosinophilic inclusion bodies in adrenal cells
Basophilic nuclear inclusion bodies in corticotroph cells

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of iatrogenic Cushing's syndrome. In this condition, the normal basophilic cytoplasm of the corticotrophs of anterior pituitary becomes homogeneous and pale. This is termed the Crooke hyaline change and is due to the accumulation of intermediate keratin filaments in the cytoplasm.

This change occurs due to high levels of circulating glucocorticoids in Cushing's syndrome. 

Based on the cause of Cushing's syndrome, the following pathological changes are seen in the adrenals:

  • Iatrogenic - atrophy of zona fasciculata and zona reticularis (as zona glomerulosa functions independently of ACTH)
  • ACTH-dependent - diffuse hyperplasia (due to high ACTH levels)
  • ACTH-independent - nodular hyperplasia, adenoma, or carcinoma

Note: Eosinophilic inclusion bodies in adrenal cells are called spironolactone bodies. They are seen in Conn's syndrome.

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Exogenous causes (iatrogenic)

  • Prolonged administration of glucocorticoids (most common cause of Cushing's)

Endogenous causes

  • ACTH independent (primary hypercortisolism)
    • Adrenocortical adenoma 
    • Adrenocortical carcinoma 
    • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia
  • ACTH dependent (secondary hypercortisolism)
    • Cushing’s disease: ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma (most common cause of endogenous Cushing's)
    • Paraneoplastic causes: Ectopic ACTH secreting tumors
      • Small-cell lung carcinoma
      • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
      • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
      • Pheochromocytoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

questions.text: What is the most common clinical feature of Cushing syndrome?
questions.solution:
Obesity is the most common clinical feature of Cushing's syndrome.

Clinical features of Cushing’s syndrome are attributed to the glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and sex steroid actions of cortisol. They include:

System Clinical features
Body fat
  • Central or truncal obesity (most common)
  • Buffalo hump (fat deposition behind the neck)
  • Moon facies  
Skin
  • Purple striae (over abdomen & flanks)
  • Acne and Hirsutism 
  • Easy bruising 
  • Facial plethora
  • Hyperpigmentation 
Musculoskeletal
  • Proximal myopathy
  • Osteoporosis
Metabolic
  • Poorly controlled hyperglycemia
  • Dyslipidemia
Reproductive
  • Oligomenorrhea
  • Amenorrhea
Renal
  • Hypokalemic alkalosis
CVS
  • Atherosclerosis 
  • Diastolic Hypertension 
  • Edema 
Hematologic
  • Hypercoagulable state 
  • Lymphopenia
  • Neutrophilia
  • Eosinopenia
CNS
  • Depression
  • Psychosis 
  • Anxiety

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the casualty with severe abdominal pain, diarrhea, and dizziness for the past 3 days. On examination, the following findings are noted. Blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg and blood glucose is 48 mg/dl. Which of the following would you expect in this patient?

choices.text: High ACTH and low renin levels
High ACTH and high renin levels
Low ACTH and normal renin levels
Low ACTH and low renin levels

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image showing hyperpigmentation of palmar creases and oral mucosa are suggestive of primary adrenal insufficiency. It presents with low aldosterone, high renin, and high ACTH levels.   

In primary adrenal insufficiency, lack of aldosterone production results in compensatory rise in ACTH and renin levels. The high ACTH results in hyperpigmentation. The most common causes are autoimmune in developed countries and tuberculosis in developing countries.

In secondary adrenal insufficiency, there is pituitary dysfunction leading to low ACTH levels. Renin and aldosterone levels are normal, as they function independently of ACTH.

Related Pearl: Causes of Adrenocortical Insufficiency

Primary adrenal insufficiency:

  • Anatomical destruction of gland
  • Autoimmune (Addison's disease)
  • Isolated autoimmune adrenalitis (polygenic)
  • Infections - HIV, tuberculosis, fungi
  • Surgical removal
  • Acute hemorrhagic necrosis (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome)
  • Amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, hemochromatosis
  • Metastatic carcinoma
  • Cytotoxic agents – mitotane
  • Enzyme inhibitors – metyrapone, ketoconazole
  • Congenital adrenal hypoplasia
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 1 (AIRE1 gene on 21q22)
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 2 (polygenic)
  • X-linked adrenal hypoplasia (DAX1 gene on Xp21)
  • Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD gene on Xq28)

Secondary adrenal insufficiency:

Hypopituitarism due to hypothalamic or pituitary disease

  • Neoplasm
  • Infiltration (sarcoidosis)
  • Infection (tuberculosis, pyogenic, fungal)

Suppression of HPA axis

  • By endogenous steroids from tumor
  • By exogenous steroids

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was referred with fever, altered sensorium, and non-blanching rash for the past 2 days. He developed rapidly progressive shock and DIC. Despite resuscitation measures, he died. The following appearance of his adrenals was noted on autopsy. All of the following can cause this condition except:
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and image showing bilateral adrenal hemorrhage are suggestive of Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is not a cause of this condition.

It is caused by highly virulent organisms such as:

  • Neisseria meningitidis or meningococci (classically)
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae or pneumococci 
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Staphylococcus species

This condition is more common in children. Overwhelming bacterial infection leads to bilateral adrenal hemorrhage, thereby causing acute adrenal insufficiency. This is likely a result of direct bacterial seeding of small vessels and endothelial dysfunction caused by microbial products and inflammatory mediators.

It usually presents with rapidly progressive hypotension and shock and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) with widespread purpura. Without prompt recognition and treatment, death occurs within hours to a few days.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of primary hyperaldosteronism?
questions.solution:
Bilateral nodular hyperplasia of the adrenal glands is the most common cause of primary hyperaldosteronism.

Adrenal adenoma is the second most common cause. It is usually solitary, but multiple adenomas may occur occasionally. Other rare causes include:

  • Ectopic aldosterone-producing tumors
  • Familial idiopathic hyperaldosteronism - due to germline mutations of KCNJ5 (encodes a potassium channel)

questions.text: What is the underlying pathology in patients with Conn's syndrome?
questions.solution:
The underlying pathology in patients with Conn's syndrome is adrenal adenoma.

Hyperaldosteronism may be primary or secondary. 

Primary hyperaldosteronism is due to autonomous overproduction of aldosterone with resultant suppression of RAAS. It can occur due to adrenal hyperplasia, adenoma, or carcinoma. It presents with the following features:

  • Hypertension (most common)
  • Hypokalemia
  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Polyuria (due to ANP)
  • Polydipsia (due to polyuria)
  • Muscle weakness

It is confirmed by elevated ratios of plasma aldosterone concentration to plasma renin activity (PAC / PRA).

When primary hyperaldosteronism is due to an aldosterone-secreting adenoma, it is called Conn syndrome. Patients are usually treated with spironolactone followed by surgical removal of adenoma. In patients treated with spironolactone, the adenomas contain eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions called spironolactone bodies.

In secondary hyperaldosteronism, aldosterone release occurs in response to the activation of the renin-angiotensin system (RAAS).

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions are not at risk of developing adrenocortical carcinoma?
questions.solution:
MEN2B syndrome is associated with pheochromocytoma and medullary carcinoma of thyroid, not adrenocortical carcinoma.

Adrenocortical carcinoma is associated with the following hereditary cancer syndromes:

  • Li–Fraumeni syndrome - due to germline TP53 mutations 
  • Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome - a disorder of epigenetic imprinting
  • MEN1 syndrome - due to mutations of MEN1 gene

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought for the evaluation of recurrent seizures over the last 3 months. Past history is significant for chronic oral candidiasis for 2 years. On examination, nail dystrophy is noted. Further investigation reveals serum calcium of 6.9 mg/dl and prolonged QT interval. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of autoimmune polyendocrinopathy (APS) type 1. It is also called APECED (autoimmune polyendocrinopathy, candidiasis, and ectodermal dystrophy).

It is caused by mutations in the autoimmune regulator (AIRE) gene. This gene usually increases tolerance of central T-cells to peripheral tissue antigens. When this function is lost, the T-cells become more prone to mount immune reactions against tissue antigens, promoting autoimmunity. These patients develop autoantibodies against IL-17 and IL-22, which are crucial for defense against fungal infections.

It presents in childhood with the following features:

  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • Ectodermal dystrophy (abnormalities of the skin, dental enamel, and nails)
  • Organ-specific autoimmune disorders such as -
    • Autoimmune adrenalitis
    • Autoimmune hypoparathyroidism
    • Idiopathic hypogonadism
    • Pernicious anemia 

Autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome (APS) type 2 usually presents in early adulthood as a combination of the following:

  • Adrenal insufficiency
  • Autoimmune thyroiditis or type 1 diabetes

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presented with recurrent episodes of palpitations, headaches, and sweating. Her BP was 155/95 mm Hg and HR was 135/min. Investigations revealed elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrines and a right adrenal mass on CT abdomen. She should be examined for the presence of all of the following except:
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of pheochromocytoma. This patient does not need to be examined for a shagreen patch. It is a feature of tuberous sclerosis syndrome, which is not associated with pheochromocytoma. 

Familial syndromes associated with pheochromocytoma are:

Syndrome Clinical manifestations
Neurofibromatosis

Café-au-lait spots

Axillary and inguinal freckling

Optic nerve glioma

Lisch nodules
von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome

Hemangioblastomas

Renal cell carcinoma

Pancreatic endocrine neoplasms
MEN2A syndrome

Medullary thyroid carcinoma

Parathyroid hyperplasia
MEN 2B syndrome

Medullary thyroid carcinoma

Marfanoid habitus

Mucocutaneous ganglioneuromatosis

Even patients with no family history must be evaluated for findings of these genetic syndromes, as they may occur sporadically in some cases.

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: Which of the following is most commonly involved in Wermer syndrome?
questions.solution:
Primary hyperparathyroidism is the most common manifestation of Wermer’s syndrome or MEN-1 syndrome.

MEN1 syndrome is due to germline mutations in the MEN1 tumor-suppressor gene, which encodes a protein called menin. The most commonly secreted products are pancreatic polypeptides.

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

questions.text: Which of the following is an indicator of malignant transformation in a patient with pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
The definitive diagnosis of malignancy in pheochromocytomas is based exclusively on the presence of metastases to regional lymph nodes as well as distant sites like liver, lung, and bone.

Capsular and vascular invasion may be encountered even in benign lesions. Malignant pheochromocytomas are histologically and biochemically the same as benign ones. Hence, typical histological criteria like cellular atypia, mitotic spindles, and vascular invasion are insufficient to confirm malignancy in pheochromocytomas.

questions.text: A pathologist is studying the following slide from the biopsy of a patient with an abdominal mass. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathology slide shows nests of cells arranged in an organoid pattern, with fibrovascular septae, and finely granular cytoplasm. This is called the zellballen pattern. It is typically seen in paragangliomas and pheochromocytomas.

Paragangliomas are benign neuroendocrine tumors arising from paraganglia in the neck or abdomen. They are composed of chief and sustentacular cells arranged in an organoid pattern.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman was being evaluated for persistent hypertension. Workup revealed a tumor located near the bifurcation of the aorta. Surgical excision was done and HPE examination revealed a zellballen pattern of cells. Where did this tumor likely originate from?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a paraganglioma (ectopic pheochromocytoma) located in the abdomen. They commonly arise from the organ of Zuckerkandl, located at the bifurcation of the aorta. It is part of the vertebral paraganglia (clusters of chromaffin cells along the autonomic nerve chains).

Other sites of origin of paragangliomas include:

  • Urinary bladder - rarely
  • Carotid and aortic bodies
  • Ganglion nodosum of the vagus nerve
  • Jugulotympanic ganglia

questions.text: What mutation is likely to be seen in patients with familial paraganglioma syndrome?
questions.solution:
Familial paraganglioma is most likely associated with mutations in the SDH (succinate dehydrogenase) gene.

The SDH complex is involved in mitochondrial electron transport and oxygen sensing. It is believed that SDH mutations also lead to the upregulation of HIF-1α, which is a key oncogenic driver in this type of tumor.

questions.text: A 21-year-old young man presents with a neck mass. Past history is significant for surgical removal of a pheochromocytoma 6 months ago. On examination, a marfanoid habitus is noted along with the following finding. Which of the following should the patient be screened for?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and image showing mucosal neuromas are suggestive of MEN2B syndrome. This condition is associated with medullary carcinoma of the thyroid. 

The MEN syndromes are a group of inherited diseases of multiple endocrine organs. Tumors occur at a younger age than sporadic tumors, either synchronously (at the same time) or metachronously (at different times).

MEN2 syndrome occurs due to abnormal activation of the RET gene. Medullary carcinoma is seen in both MEN 2A and 2B syndromes. However, it tends to be more aggressive and metastasizes more frequently in MEN2B syndrome.

Note: RET gene is deactivated in Hirschsprung disease.

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: What gene is mutated in polycythemia paraganglioma syndrome?
questions.solution:
Polycythemia paraganglioma syndrome occurs due to germline mutations in the EPAS1 gene. This syndrome presents with neuroendocrine tumors and early-onset polycythemia.

RET gene mutation is seen in MEN2A and MEN2B syndromes.

SDHD and SDHB mutations are seen in hereditary paraganglioma 1 and hereditary paraganglioma 4 syndromes respectively.
